title: Primitive Set
content: A set A ⊆ ℕ is primitive if no member divides another. Equivalently, it forms an antichain in the divisibility poset.

title: Primes Form a Primitive Set
content: The set of prime numbers is primitive because if p | q for primes p, q, then p = q (by definition of prime).

title: The Sum Σ 1/(n log n)
content: For n ≥ 2, define f(n) = 1/(n log n). The primitive sum of a set A is the sum Σ_{n ∈ A} f(n), defined as the supremum of finite sums.

title: Erdős Convergence Theorem (1935)
content: For any primitive set A, the sum Σ 1/(n log n) converges to a finite value. This was proved by Erdős in 1935.

title: Lichtman's Theorem (2023)
content: The primes maximize Σ 1/(n log n) among all primitive sets. Moreover, the primes are the unique maximizer.

title: Why Primes Are Special
content: Primes are the 'atoms' of multiplicative structure - every integer > 1 has unique prime factorization. This makes primes extremal for many properties of primitive sets.

title: Related Sums and Densities
content: Similar questions arise for other sums like Σ 1/(n(log n)^{1+ε}). The Besicovitch density of any primitive set is 0.

title: Lichtman's Proof Strategy
content: The proof uses a comparison argument showing that replacing non-primes with primes increases the sum, leveraging the multiplicative structure of integers.

title: Functions Maximized by Primes
content: A function g: ℕ → ℝ is 'maximized by primes' if for any primitive set A, the sum Σ g(n) over A is at most the sum over primes. The function 1/(n log n) has this property.

title: Main Result and Summary
content: Erdős Problem #164 is SOLVED: The primes uniquely maximize Σ 1/(n log n) among all primitive sets (Lichtman 2023).
